steps.content:
Each cell in the attached spreadsheet represents a plot of land. The color of the cell indicates who owns that plot. Green cells are plots owned by Earl Smith. Can Earl walk through every plot he owns (and no other plots) and return to his starting plot without backtracking? For this question, consider backtracking to be any instance where Earl would enter a plot of land he had already entered since leaving his starting plot.
XLSX document content:
## Sheet1
|
|  |

plan: Open the provided XLSX document to view the spreadsheet content.
Identify all the green cells in the spreadsheet, which represent the plots owned by Earl Smith.
Create a graph representation of the green cells, where each cell is a node and edges represent possible paths between adjacent green cells.
Check if there is a Hamiltonian circuit in the graph, which would allow Earl to walk through every plot he owns and return to the starting plot without backtracking.
If a Hamiltonian circuit exists, conclude that Earl can walk through all his plots as described; otherwise, conclude that he cannot.

facts_to_lookup.name: spreadsheet_content
facts_to_lookup.description: The content of the spreadsheet, specifically the layout and color coding of the cells.

facts_to_derive.name: green_cells_coordinates
facts_to_derive.description: The coordinates of all green cells in the spreadsheet representing plots owned by Earl Smith.

facts_to_derive.name: graph_representation
facts_to_derive.description: A graph representation of the green cells, where each cell is a node and edges represent possible paths between adjacent green cells.

facts_to_derive.name: hamiltonian_circuit_exists
facts_to_derive.description: Whether a Hamiltonian circuit exists in the graph representation, allowing Earl to walk through all his plots and return to the starting plot without backtracking.
